comment._content:
Likely a gathering of New York socialites in the "Belgian Relief Shop":
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/6482045033/]

Here's another image of Margaret Andrews (rightmost in main image above) from the Bain collection:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3842046949/]

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Muriel Egerton Winthrop (1894-, daughter of Egerton L. Winthrop, was a champion amateur equestrian in Newport RI, 1912; she married Richard De Blois Boardman in 1921, and married a second time, to Harold Aymar Sands, in 1925.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: @blor: you are right. Here's another photo of the same group that was published in the New York Times memory.loc.gov/service/sgp/sgpnyt/1914/191412/19141206/00... on Dec 6, 1914. The caption is "Society girls who are daily foragers for "Little Belguim[sic]" the Fifth Avenue shop.

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: bior and swanq:  Thanks for linking this photo to the Belgian Relief Shop.  We'll include this link next time we update.  pennylrichards: Thanks for providing additional information about Muriel Winthrop.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] 
The group is almost, but not exactly the same in the Times.  "Miss Morgan" is identified as Camilla Morgan.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: In July 1917, a Miss Camilla Morgan, who was a prominent suffragist in New York City, married Ensign James C. White of the Massachusetts Naval Reserve, at the home of his godmother, Mrs. T. F. Richardson, at Cohasset MA. (The wedding was secret, so it was only announced several weeks later, in a short note in the New York Times, 10 August 1917.) They had a daughter born in New York City within a couple years after they married. James (1895-1981) eventually became Chief of Neurosurgery at Massachusetts General Hospital: neurosurgery.mgh.harvard.edu/white/default.htm westnsurg.org/society/bio.aspx?MemberID=2879
